channel.name: Is there a way to prove a smart contract method directly without having to wrap it as transaction?

messages.content: One possibility is to create a replica of your target blockchain and conduct a trial transaction to test the method's viability locally. I have seen this before on evm chain. https://youtu.be/Noxik2pZWV4

Note: Some dApps will not work properly with the interceptor's "simulation stack" mod...

messages.content: would be a nice proposal thou :p
is this what you are looking for?
No, not really i think 🙂
explain your goal and issue
i want to get a proof of the `deposit` method's circuit
why don't you just test your circuit seperately
https://github.com/WalletZkApp/zkapp-keyless-wallet/blob/main/src/Guardian.test.ts

embeds.title: zkapp-keyless-wallet/Guardian.test.ts at main · WalletZkApp/zkapp-k...
embeds.description: Mina Protocol: Smart Contract Keyless wallet uses Social Recovery and SmartOTP's to allow users to restore access to their accounts without revealing any personal information of the users a...

messages.content: sorry, this isn't what i am after at all.
Well, I don't see the use in this. The public input if a SC proof is an AccountUpdate and the transaction wrapper just provides a method to generate that public input
shouldnt it be the case that each method is a circuit on its own? or is the entire smart contract a large circuit?
there is a standalone prover for each method afaik
there is a `SmartContract.Proof`, so i'm looking for a way to generate that proof for a method
but there is a single verification key, yet multiple provers for each method
i think @gregor might be able to help, i'm looking for a way to run a method prover, that does not rely on any account updates at all, therefore there should be no public input?
Simplest way I can think of is to run your method code in a ZkProgram. You should have the code in a method without `@method` decorator so that it's not wrapped with zkapp assumptions
@maht0rz
ok sure that makes sense as well
how about `SimpleContract._provers['myMethod']() -> gives me a proof?`
is there any way to resonable introspect what args the prover will look for?
it needs parameters, and expects a public input
yes, we call the prover in account_update.ts --> addMissingProofs
yep yep looking at that now
`zkAppProver.run` is an essential part of that though
it provides the arguments
the prover doesn't take private inputs as arguments. instead it'll look for them in a global context
the only arguments are public inputs and proofs to be verified
i see let me experiment a bit with ZkProgram directly
can proofs be introduced as private input through Circuit.witness?
cc @Istvan
i can't seem to find an example of recursive proofs in the snarky examples 🤔
doesnt type check with Circuit.witness, but can be used as a @method argument?
@gregor ^ if you could find a moment to check this out, i wasnt able to find an example in the snarky repo
No @maht0rz, the idea is that you use proofs as method arguments
let me find an example
because they can't be private arguments?
huh
no they are private arguments
Just being curious and kinda off-topic: Can you verify more than two proofs in one method? No, right?
@maht0rz this example uses proofs as method arguments: https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/80e7619aac0e6a53ccc0c96e46d35fbedefa13c9/src/examples/zkapps/simple_zkapp_with_proof.ts#L33-L37
thx ^
And yes @rpanic  -- as the example shows you can do two 😄
But more than two?
no!
one two? what do you guys mean i lost the thread 😄
ah, amount of proofs as args
@gregor are zk programs subject to the same circuit size limits as methods?
Yes @maht0rz
@maht0rz @gregor has this issue been solved?
yes
Awesome thank you @maht0rz
